content:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/777
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/775

I don't know if they are students trying to contribute to OSS projects in weird ways.
Those are PRs for hacktoberfest hence the "please don't mark as invalid"
you could mark them spam, works the same :upside_down:

Well the digitalocean website (https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/) states

If a maintainer reports your pull request as spam or behavior not in line with the project’s code of conduct, you will be ineligible to participate.

So this is definitely not the intended way of participating :grinning:

kennytm said:

you could mark them spam, works the same :upside_down:

The PR pages don't show report button for PR body. We could go to the user page to report them,
but neh, one more step.
Simply labeling the PR as invalid suffices for it to not count
only the maintainers have that permission. I could only report it here.
related blogpost: https://blog.domenic.me/hacktoberfest/
One repo just closed 12 Spam Pull-Requests that were created between 12 and 6 hours ago.
These spammers get really crazy right now
This one "fixes" the projects name: https://github.com/exercism/python/pull/2228/files
DO responded: https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/hacktoberfest-update
I appreciate that we have a spam label that's description is literally "for marking spam during Hacktoberfest" :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

I don't think that the levels of abuse developers are casually expected to 'just
manage' could be any more tangible
Why did rustc-perf in particular receive these?
Maybe someone saw it and decided to make a PR and told their friends...

Not sure but if anyone feels like they're missing out I'd be happy to let them
know they're awesome: https://github.com/jonniedie/SharedMATLABEngine.jl/pull/5

If I were to do this, shipping costs for a t-shirt would probably get so high that I'd have to pay customs to my country. I can imagine better ways of wasting time and money. But wow, that "I'm 100% accepting this" response was just pure gold :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

to be honest I am saddened and I find this whole story unfortunate. Adding stress, burden and additional work on maintainers (often unpaid) for a ... tshirt? That's beyond my comprehension. The response from D.O. also left me unimpressed. But, well, this is the world we live in, I guess.

apiraino said:

to be honest I am saddened and I find this whole story unfortunate. Adding stress, burden and additional work on maintainers (often unpaid) for a ... tshirt? That's beyond my comprehension. The response from D.O. also left me unimpressed. But, well, this is the world we live in, I guess.

Same here :/
Update: https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/hacktoberfest-update
Tldr: only repositories which are opted in and prs that are merged will be considered

We’ve traced the majority of this year’s spammy contributions back to a participant with a large online audience who openly encouraged their community to take part in spammy activities, including ideas on how to game the system. However, we know the spam issues go beyond this one example. This is an aspect of Hacktoberfest we have been working to improve since we started the program seven years ago.
Nb. spam might not work: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=24644640, invalid might be better
